Incident.Summary: The suspect was arrested for DUI/DWI, failure to obey lawful order, and hindering & obstructing. The suspect was in possession of cannabis civil amount.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
In-Car (L-21) and Body Worn Camera Operational.
  • Defendant: Jeral Golden Burrell
  • Date of Birth: 07/23/1991
  • Date of Arrest: 05/05/2023
  • Time of Arrest: 2301


DUI:

    23-141

Certificate and Training:

    Trained in Administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests (SFSTs) through the Maryland State Police (MSP) and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA)

    Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (A.R.I.D.E.)

Soundex:

    B-640-402-285-579/Maryland

Scene Processing:

    One clear mason jar containing suspected raw cannabis was located on the passenger floorboard of the vehicle.

Physical Evidence:

    The following evidence was captured on an MSP Form 63 and an MSP Form 67, held accordingly to MSP policy and procedure, and stored in the MSP Forestville Temporary Evidence Locker.

    One (1) Uniform Civil Citation (6Z46647614) is attached to this report.

    Five (5) digital photograph of the CDS is attached to this report.

P-339204:
  1. One ziplock bag containing suspected raw cannabis. Weight: 19.4 grams with bag



Narrative:
VEHICLE IN MOTION (Phase 1):

    On May 5, 2023, at approximately 2230 hours, I, Trooper J. Barlow #7186, of the Maryland State Police, currently assigned to the Forestville Barrack, was on duty in my marked patrol vehicle traveling northbound Crain Highway at Missouri Avenue, Cheltenham, Prince George’s County, Maryland 20623 in lane 1 of a 2-lane road. Traffic conditions were moderate with approximately three cars ahead of me and a few more to the rear of me. I observed one of the vehicles ahead of me, a white Chevrolet Silverado bearing Maryland registration “091Z36” was traveling in lane 2 failing to drive right of center. The Silverado crossed the lane divider lines by more than a half car length nearly striking the vehicle traveling to its left in lane 1. The Silverado then proceeded to make a lane change into lane 1 where it then crossed over the solid yellow boundary line by more than a half car length. At this time, I positioned my vehicle behind the Silverado to create distance between it and the other vehicles on the roadway. I observed the vehicle continue to drive in the same reckless manner for less than a half mile. I activated my emergency equipment and conducted a traffic stop on the vehicle northbound Crain Highway at Cheltenham Drive, Cheltenham, Prince George’s County, Maryland 20623.

PERSONAL CONTACT (Phase 2):

    Upon stopping the vehicle, I made a passenger side approach where I observed the vehicle was occupied two times. The driver advised his passenger window did not roll down, so I approached the driver side of the vehicle. While talking to the driver, I advised him I stopped him for failing to drive right of center and requested his driver’s license and registration card. I identified the driver by his Maryland driver’s license as Jeral Golden Burrell (B/M DOB: 07/23/1991.) Burrell did not provide me with the registration card after requesting it approximately 2-3 times. I observed Burrell’s eyes to be glossy and bloodshot red. I detected Burrell’s speech to be low and slurred. I asked Burrell why was he unable to stay within his lane of travel to which he stated, “I’m just trying to get home bruh.” I asked Burrell where is home to which he said his address, but due to his speech, part of the house number and street name faded out in translation. I asked Burrell where he was coming from to which he stated, “I’m just picking my daughter up,” who was the other occupant asleep in the vehicle. Burrell reached into the glove compartment looking for his registration card and was talking at the same time. I was unable to hear what Burrell was talking about due to his low volume. Burrell attempted to hand me a Department of Transportation (DOT) card, but I did not need nor requested it. Burrell was still unable to locate the registration card. When I asked for the registration card one more time, Burrell sated, “You can google it. Put it in your system, its registered.” I asked Burrell how many alcoholic beverages had he consumed to which Burrell stated, “I had one beer.” I asked Burrell how long ago did he consume the beer to which he stated, “About 2 hours ago.” I asked Burrell what was the name of the beer to which he stated, “Apple Cider.” I asked Burrell where did he consume the beer and he advised he did not remember. Burrell began to ask me what is the process or next steps, but began to stutter while he spoke. Burrell’s speech was still low in volume but was understandable. I requested Burrell to perform voluntary Standardized Field Sobriety Tests (SFSTs) to which he agreed to perform, then immediately refused. Burrell began making requests I follow him home since he lives close or to call his father to pick him up. Burrell proceeded to wake up his daughter. At this time while waiting for an additional unit to respond to the scene, Burrell advised all of this was unnecessary, and he and his daughter just left from the movie theater. Burrell began speaking racial biases about the additional unit responding to the scene stating, “Is he white, you got a white officer coming.” Burrell kept his hands on the steering wheel and was compliant at this time. Burrell reiterated he had a beer and took his daughter out for the night.

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (Phase 3):

    At approximately 2247 hours, Prince George’s County Police Officer Sergeant Banks #1913 arrived on scene. Burrell was requested to exit the vehicle twice before I opened the car door. Burrell complied with commands and exited the vehicle where he was detained. A pat down was conducted to be sure he was not carrying any firearms or drugs on his person. I asked Burrell if he had any weapons or drugs on him to which Burrell stated, “Drugs meaning what?” I advised Burrell of a list of drugs, one being cannabis to which he stated, “I got marijuana.” I asked Burrell where is it located, in his pockets or the car to which Burrell stated, “It’s in the car.” When asked where in the car is it located Burrell repeatedly stated “It’s right there” not giving a specific location within the vehicle. I asked Burrell once again if he wanted to perform SFSTs to which he agreed to perform. Prior to performing SFSTs, I turned off my front facing equipment and turned away my spotlight. I removed the handcuffs from Burrell’s wrists as well. I asked Burrell if he wears glasses, takes any medication, or has any injuries which would hinder him from walking in a straight line or standing on one leg for any duration of time to which he advised no.

Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (HGN) 6 out of 6 clues observed:

    Before performing HGN, I instructed Burrell to stand with his legs and feet together with his arms down by his sides. I instructed Burrell not to move from this position until I instructed him to do so. I asked Burrell if he could see the silver tip of my stimulus to which he advised he could. I instructed Burrell to follow the silver tip of my stimulus with his eyes only, without moving his head, neck, or shoulders. I asked Burrell if he understood the instructions I gave him to which he advised he did. Burrell exhibited equal pupil size and Resting Nystagmus was not present. While testing for equal tracking, Burrell moved his head after being instructed not to. After resetting Burrell to continue the test, Burrell continued to move his head again. Burrell continued to move his head throughout the test. During the test, Burrell stopped following the stimulus completely on multiple occasions. Burrell would look at me in my eyes instead of looking at the stimulus.

Lack of Smooth Pursuit:

    Burrell showed lack of smooth pursuit in both eyes.

Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation:

    Burrell showed distinct and sustained nystagmus at maximum deviation.

Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees:

    Burrell showed onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees.

Vertical Gaze Nystagmus:

    Burrell did not show vertical gaze nystagmus.

Walk and Turn (WAT) 2 out of 8 clues observed:

    Before performing WAT, I instructed Burrell to imagine there was a straight line in front of him and to place his right foot in front of his left foot touching heel to toe. I instructed Burrell not to move from this position until I instructed him to do so. I instructed Burrell to take nine (9) heel to toe steps down the imaginary line, looking down at his feet, and counting each stop out loud. I instructed Burrell once he got to his 9th step, leave his lead foot planted and take a series of small steps turning around to his left and take 9 more heel to toe steps back down the imaginary line. I instructed Burrell once he starts the test, do not stop the test until he completed the test. While providing the instructions, Burrell interrupted me multiple times advising the instructions were too much. Burrell began trying to simplify the instructions himself as I attempted to re-explain it to him. As I was explaining the test to Burrell he stated, “I’m not understanding nothing you’re talking about right now. I’ve been standing in a straight line this whole time, I’m not that drunk nigga.” I asked Burrell if he wanted to complete this portion of the test to which he advised he was trying to. Burrell was currently out of instructional phase position and stated, “This ain’t gonna happen, this ain’t gonna happen. What you want me to do?” I requested Burrell to get back in to the starting position to continue with the instructions. Burrell began to lift his knees up to his chest one at a time sort of in the manner of stretching. I asked Burrell if he is going to do this portion of the test to which he advised he was but was continuously being uncooperative and noncompliant with instructions. Clues observed from this portion of the test did not go beyond the instructional phase. I deemed Burrell unfit to continue in the process of performing SFSTs.

Instructional Phase:

    Burrell lost balance during the instructional phase, separating his feet by more than one half inch.

    Burrell started too soon during the instructional phase.


One Leg Stand (OLS) 0 out of 4 clues observed:

    Due to Burrell’s severe lack of cooperation during WAT, Burrell was unable to perform the OLS portion of SFSTs.

Arrest:
  • Failure to drive right of center
  • Glossy eyes
  • Low and slow speech
  • The moderate odor of alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath
  • The admission of consuming alcoholic beverage
  • The observations during SFSTs
  • Failure to obey lawful order
  • Obstructing and Hindering police official

Preliminary Breath Test:

    Refused

    At approximately 2301 hours, Burrell was placed under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol. Burrell was advised of his Preliminary Breath Test (PBT) rights and offered a PBT to which he refused. Burrell was advised to enter my marked patrol vehicle where he began to be verbally combative and refused to enter the vehicle. Burrell continued to yell at Sergeant Banks about his daughter still being in the vehicle. I advised Burrell we would take care of his daughter, and she would not be left here in the vehicle alone. Burrell insisted we call his father to come to the scene and retrieve his daughter and vehicle. In an attempt to deescalate the situation, I agreed to call Burrell’s father as long as he got into the vehicle as requested. Burrell agreed to the condition, but once Sergeant Banks called his father, due to Burrell’s loud yelling, Sergeant Banks walked away to be able to hear the phone conversation. Burrell continued yelling and refusing to enter the vehicle. At this time Burrell then stepped up on the base of my door frame, where I then used force to remove Burrell from the door frame. Once on the ground, force was used to get Burrell into the vehicle. After Burrell was seated in the front passenger seat of the vehicle, Burrell extended his right leg into the door of the vehicle, continuing to refuse to enter. I then grabbed the back of Burrell’s knee with my left hand and his shin with my right hand to bend his leg into the vehicle. Once Burrell was successfully placed into the vehicle seat belted, and compliance was gained, all use of force seized. There were no injuries sustained by either party. Sergeant Banks was on the opposite end of the vehicle at the time force was used, therefore, he did not witness nor use force himself. After Burrell was secured in the vehicle, Sergeant Banks stood by watching Burrell while I went to check on Burrell’s daughter who was standing outside of the vehicle at this time. While talking to Burrell’s daughter trying to keep her calm and wait for her grandparents to arrive on scene, Burrell managed to unbuckle the seatbelt and open the passenger door. Burrell was placed back into the vehicle and seat belted once again. While talking to the daughter, she advised her name is Naomi. I attempted to advised Naomi to sit in the vehicle where she continued to have a temper tantrum. In an attempt to physically place Naomi into the vehicle, Naomi decided to place her feet in the seat refusing to enter the vehicle. After multiple attempts trying to get Naomi into the vehicle, she slipped past me and walked out into the front of the vehicle. Again, I had to physically lift Naomi up to bring her back to a safe area of the vehicle. At this time Naomi finally complied with my request to sit in the vehicle to wait for her grandparents to arrive on scene.

    Shortly after getting Naomi in the vehicle, at approximately 2335 hours, Darrell Lee Burrell (B/M DOB: 09/17/1964) and Andrea Lean Burrell (B/F DOB: 05/30/1964) arrived on scene. Darrell advised his granddaughter's name is Naomi Aletha Burrell (B/F DOB: 03/31/2016.) Darrell and Andrea took custody of Naomi and possession of the Silverado.

    Prior to Darrell taking possession of the Silverado, a search incident to arrest was conducted on the vehicle. At approximately 2339 hours, a clear mason jar containing suspected raw cannabis was located on the passenger floorboard.

    All CDS was identified by my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper and previous CDS arrests.

    Burrell was transported to the Forestville Barrack for processing. While at the Barrack, Burrell was provided a digital copy of the Advice of Rights (DR-015) from the mva.maryland.gov website to follow along while I played the audio version of the form downloaded from the same website in its entirety.

Intoximeter Test:

    Refused.

    After having been read the DR-015, at approximately 0019 hours, Burrell refused to submit to the Intoximeter Test.

    Burrell was charged with DUI/DWI, traffic related incidents, criminal misdemeanor charges, and a Uniform Civil Citation (6Z46647614) for the possession of cannabis.

    Due to Burrell’s unpredictable behavior, inability to cooperate and compliance level, Burrell was detained at the Barrack in Cell 1 while handcuffed to the front. With Burrell refusing to do anything else asked of him, Burrell was unable to sign any documents which were issued to him for this incident.

    Burrell was transported to Upper Marlboro Department of Corrections.

    Case closed by arrest.

    All events occurred in Prince George’s County, Maryland.

IncidentProperty.Description: One ziplock bag containing suspected raw cannabis.
